questions.text: All the following mediate their action using cAMP a second messenger except:
questions.solution:
- Dopamine has 5 receptors, all of which uses cAMP as second messenger. Receptors D, & D5 act by increasing cAMP whereas D2, D3, & D4 by decreasing it

- Vasopressin (ADH) has 3 receptors of which vasopressin receptor 1 (V1A) in vascular smooth muscles act via IP3/DAG mechanism whereas receptor 2 (V2) in tubular epithelial cells (important for water reabsorption) acts through cAMP - adenyl cyclase system

questions.text: All of the following bind to the steroid receptors
questions.solution: Steroid receptors bind to hormones, hormone response elements (HRE), and, transcriptional co-activators and transcriptional mediator related protein

questions.text: Adrenaline, noradrenaline and dopamine act through
questions.solution: catecholamines (epinephrine, norepinephrine and dopamine) act through G protein coupled receptors, which span the cell membrane 7 times; hence also referred to as seven pass (seven helix) or serpentine receptors

choices.text: Decreasing the activity of suprachiasmatic nuclei
Blocking the release of norepinephrine from sympathetic nerve terminals

questions.text: Exposure to darkness leads to increased melatonin secretion. It is brought about by:
questions.solution: Increased N-acetyl transferase and hydroxy indole-o-methyl (HOM) transferase during darkness leads to increased melatonin secretion.

choices.text: Decreased rate of glucose uptake by cells

questions.text: Somatomedin mediates:
questions.solution: Growth hormone exerts much of its effects (especially on growth, cartilage & protein metabolism) through intermediate polypeptide growth factors also k/a somatomedin or insulin like growth factor secreted by liver & other tissues. Somatomedin was called sulfation factor because it stimulated incorporation of sulfate into cartilage leading to deposition of chondroitin sulfate and collagen formation.

questions.text: A small Ca+2 binding protein that modifies the activity of many enzymes and other proteins in response to changes of Ca2+ concentration, is known as:
questions.solution: Calmodulin is a small Ca2+ binding protein that modifies activity of many enzymes/proteins in response to changes of Ca2+

questions.text: Secondary hyperparathyroidism due to Vit deficiency shows:
questions.solution: PTH increases phosphate excretion in urine causing hypophosphatemia. This causes phosphaturia, hypophosphatemia. This phosphaturic action is due to decreased reabsorption of phosphate in distal tubules.

questions.text: Maximum insulin secretion at physiological conditions is seen with administration of
questions.solution: Insulin is secreted along with C-peptide in a 1:1 ratio. Half-life of human insulin is 5 minutes. Glucose mediated insulin release is mediated through ATP dependent K+ channels, Insulin secretion is inhibited by epinephrine (adrenaline) and increased by gastrin, secretin, GIP, CCK, glucose, vagal stimulation and acetyl choline

choices.text: Tumours of adrenal medulla secrete epinephrine in excess of norepinephrine
Adrenal medullary secretion predominates with dopamine > epinephrine > norepinephrine
Adrenal medulla is not triggered by ACTH
Chromaffin granules are seen in pheochromocytoma

questions.text: All of the following statements about adrenals are true except:
questions.solution: In health, 80% of output from adrenal medulla is epinephrine & only 20% is noradrenaline.

questions.text: Mineralocorticoid receptors are present in all of the following sites, Except:
questions.solution:
Mineralocorticoid (aldosterone) receptors are not found in liver. Much of Aldosterone is metabolized in liver to 40% tetrahydroglucuronide, 5% acid labile conjugate & < 1% free aldosterone appear in urine.

Mineral corticoid receptors are present in collecting tubules (principal cells), distal tubules & collecting ducts kidney, sweat glands, salivary glands, and intestinal epithelium especially in colon causing conservation (reabsorption) of Na+ & water and secretion (excretion) of K+ & HCO3. These receptors are also found in bran. (hippocampus), myocardium, muscle, vessels (peripheral vasculature) and brown adipose tissue.

questions.text: The effect of cortisol on metabolism in liver is all except
questions.solution: Glucocorticoid is anti-insulin hormone that is catabolic to peripheral tissues and anabolic to liver. So, in liver it increases glycogen and protein synthesis and gluconeogenesis whereas, in peripheral tissue it causes hyper glycemia (d/t decreased glucose uptake and decreased glycolysis), increased free fatty acids & aminoacids in plasma (d/t increased lipolysis and proteolysis respectively)

questions.text: Excess secretion of aldosterone causes all except
questions.solution: Hyperaldosteronism (excess mineralocorticoid) leads to potassium (K+) depletion / hypokalemia and sodium (Na+) retention, usually without edema but with weakness tetany, polyuria, hypertension and hypokalemic mild metabolic alkalosis, And plasma Na+ level is elevated only slightly if at all because water is retained with osmotically active Na+ ions

questions.text: Beta HCG is secreted by
questions.solution: βHCG (human chorionic gonadotropin) is secreted by syncytiotrophoblast of placenta.

choices.text: Post hormonal therapy breast enlargement in postmenopausal females

questions.text: What is thelarche?
questions.solution: • In girls, at puberty, thelarche (breast development/enlargement) is the first event, followed by puberty (development of pubic & axillary hair) and then by menarche (first menstrual period). Estrogen is responsible for thelarche.

questions.text: Which of the following sugar is/are found in Amniotic fluid?
questions.solution: Glucose is the sugar found in amniotic fluid

questions.text: Ovarian reserve is best indicated by
questions.solution: Ovarian reserve can be best assessed by measuring FSH levels on 3rd day of menstrual cycle. Serum inhibin B level and ultrasonic scanning to count the number of antral follicles in ovary is an alternative method.

questions.text: A 37-year-old woman presents to her physician with an enlarged thyroid gland and high plasma levels of T4 and T3. Which of the following is likely to be decreased?
questions.solution: Because of the effects of thyroid hormones to increase metabolism in tissues, tissues vasodilate, thus increasing blood flow and cardiac output. All the other choices increase in response to high plasma levels of thyroid hormones

questions.text: A 35-year-old female presents to the OPD with headaches and high blood pressure. On investigation, increased aldosterone levels with low renin levels are seen and a diagnosis of Conn's Syndrome is made. Excess secretion of aldosterone can cause all except?
questions.solution:
• Excess secretion of aldosterone causes a modest increase in plasma sodium, usually <4-6 mEq/L increase.
  • A small tumor of the zona glomerulosa cells occurs and secretes large amounts of aldosterone; the resulting condition is called primary aldosteronism or Conn-s syndrome.
  • The most important effects are as follows:
    • Hypokalemia
    • Mild metabolic alkalosis
    • A slight increase in extracellular fluid volume and blood volume not to the point of edema formation. As excess fluid is eliminated by kidneys (Aldosterone escape mechanism)
    • A modest increase in plasma sodium concentration (usually <4 to 6 mEq/L increase)
    • Loss of potassium by the kidneys
    • Almost always, hypertension

questions.text: The Iodine is transported into the thyroid gland by:
questions.solution:
• The sodium-iodide symporter (NIS) is located on the basal aspect of the follicular cell membrane. This symporter uses Na+ gradient across the membrane to transport 1 iodide along with 2 Na+ into the cytosol of the follicular cell. It is a secondary active transport; Na+-K+-ATPase would be required to pump Na+ out of the cell and maintain the Na+ gradient.
  • The NIS can bind and transport other anions, such as thiocyanate, perchlorate, and bromide. This may be used to reduce iodide uptake by the gland.

Iodide enters the follicular cell (against its electrochemical gradient) via NIS situated on the basal aspect of the membrane. Then, on the apical membrane of the follicular cell, a protein pendrin mediates transport of the iodide from the follicular cell into the follicle. Pendrin is a member of the SAT family of anion exchangers (SAT: sulfate-anion transporter).

choices.text: Zona glomerulosa is involved in formation of new cortical cells.
ACTH has little hypertrophic effect on the zona glomerulosa.
80% of the cholesterol used for steroid synthesis is provided by low-density lipoproteins

questions.text: Which of the following is true regarding adrenal steroid hormone synthesis?
questions.solution:
• 80 percent of the cholesterol used for steroid synthesis is provided by low-density lipoproteins (LDLs) in the circulating plasma. The LDLs release the cholesterol inside the adrenal cells that can be used to synthesize adrenal steroid hormones.
  • Aldosterone and cortisol secretion are regulated by independent mechanisms. Factors such as angiotensin II that specifically increase the output of aldosterone and cause hypertrophy of the zona glomerulosa have no effect on the other two zones. Similarly, factors such as ACTH that increase secretion of cortisol and adrenal androgens and cause hypertrophy of the zona fasciculata and zona reticularis have little effect on the zona glomerulosa.
  • An important function of the zona glomerulosa, in addition to aldosterone synthesis, is the formation of new cortical cells.  The adrenal medulla does not regenerate, but when the inner two zones of the cortex are removed, a new zona fasiciculata and zona reticularis regenerate from glomerular cells attached to the capsule.

questions.text: Derivatives of pro-opio-melanocortin in pituitary gland is ?
questions.solution:
• In corticotropes of the anterior pituitary, POMC (Proopiomelanocortin) is hydrolyzed to ACTH and β-lipotropin (LPH), plus a small amount of β-endorphin and these substances are secreted.
  • In the intermediate lobe cells of the pituitary gland, POMC is hydrolyzed to corticotropin-like intermediate-lobe peptide (CLIP), γ-LPH (lipotropin), and appreciable quantities of β-endorphin. The melanotropins α- and β-MSH are also formed.

The intermediate lobe in humans is rudimentary, and it appears that neither α-MSH nor β-MSH is secreted in adults

questions.text: Which symptom would least likely be associated with thyrotoxicosis?
questions.solution: Thyrotoxicosis indicates the effects of thyroid hormone excess. Thyroid hormone excites synapses. In contrast, somnolence is characteristic of hypothyroidism. Tachycardia, increased appetite, increased sweating, and muscle tremor are all signs of hyperthyroidism

questions.text: Cortisone is administered to a 30-year-old woman for the treatment of an autoimmune disease. Which of the following is most likely to occur?
questions.solution: Steroids with potent glucocorticoid activity tend to increase plasma glucose concentration. As a result insulin secretion is stimulated. Increased glucocorticoid activity also diminishes muscle protein. Because of feedback, cortisone administration leads to a decrease in adrenocorticotropic hormone secretion and, therefore, a decrease in plasma cortisol concentration

choices.text: They stimulate the activity of osteoblasts
They stimulate calcium reabsorption by the renal tubule
They stimulate parathyroid hormone (PTH) secretion by the parathyroid gland
They increase absorption of calcium from the gastrointestinal tract

questions.text: After menopause, hormone replacement therapy with estrogen-like compounds is effective in preventing the progression of osteoporosis. What is the mechanism of their protective effect?
questions.solution: Estrogen compounds are believed to have an osteoblast- stimulating effect. When the amount of estrogen in the blood falls to very low levels after menopause, the balance between the bone-building activity of the osteoblasts and the bone-degrading activity of the osteoclasts is tipped toward bone degradation. When estrogen compounds are added as part of hormone replacement therapy, the bone-building activity of the osteoblasts is increased to balance the osteoclastic activity

questions.text: cGMP is the second messenger of ?
questions.solution:
Vasodilatory actions of NO are mediated by cGMP.

  • NO is derived from amino acid arginine by action of enzyme eNOS (endothelium derived nitric oxide synthase).
  • NO activates soluble guanylyl cyclases in vascular smooth muscle cells resulting in conversion of cGTP to cGMP (2nd messenger).
  • cGMP activates cGMP dependent protein kinase which cause blood vessels to relax.
  • cGMP is the second messenger for Nitric oxide and atrial natriuretic factor

choices.text: Controls the rate of formation of 1, 25-dihydroxycholicalciferol
Controls the rate of calcium transport in the mucosa of the small intestine
Controls the rate of formation of calcium-binding protein

questions.text: Direct action of parathormone among the following is?
questions.solution: Parathyroid hormone acts in the renal cortex to stimulate the reaction forming 1, 25-dihydroxycholicalciferol from 25-hydroxycholicalciferol. It has no effects on other the other reactions

questions.text: Dwarfism is caused by all except?
questions.solution:
• Thyroid hormones are essential for normal growth and development. If thyroid deficiency occurs in children, any time before the fusion of the epiphyses of the long bones, it leads to growth retardation or arrest. Loss in height that occurs due to this, may be recovered after the administration of thyroid hormone. This is called catch-up growth However, the mental development which also gets arrested or retarded may not be normalized even with thyroid administration.
  • GH deficiency before puberty leads to dwarfism. GH-receptor unresponsiveness leads to Larons dwarfism.

Castration or extirpation of testes, before puberty, would result in permanent sterility. Absence of testosterone leads to failure of usual pubertal changes to occur, and accessory organs of reproduction do not develop. There is some delay in the closure of epiphyses of long bones, due to absence of testosterone. However, it does not result in dwarfism. Castration after puberty will cause atrophy of the seminal vesicles and prostate. Sexual desire and erection may be absent

questions.text: Thyroxine binding globulin (TBG) is increased in:
questions.solution:
• TBG concentration increases in conditions of high estrogen levels, such as pregnancy or oral contraceptives.
  • TBG concentration is decreased by: (i) Hormones androgens, glucocorticoids; (ii) malnutrition, nephrotic syndrome, cancer chemotherapy.
  • TBG binding of thyroid hormones is decreased by drugs, such as phenytoin, salicylates.

questions.text: Continuous administration of GnRH?
questions.solution:
• Continuous administration of GnRH suppresses the hypothalamic pituitary axis.
  • Although pulsatile GnRH discharge stimulates a corresponding pulsatile release of LH and FSH, continuous administration of GnRH-or intermittent administration of high doses of GnRH analogues-suppresses the release of gonadotropins. (suppresses the hypothalamic-pituitary axis).
  • The mechanism is inhibition of the replenishment of GnRH receptors so that insufficient receptors are available for GnRH function.
  • A clinical application of this principle is in prostatic cancer, in which the administration of GnRH analogs lowers LH and FSH levels and thereby reduces testosterone production (i.e., chemical castration).

choices.text: Plasma levels of endogenous hormone are high
Plasma levels of endogenous hormone are low

questions.text: If a radioimmunoassay is properly conducted and the amount of radioactive hormone bound to antibody is low, what would this result indicate?
questions.solution: In a radioimmunoassay, there is too little antibody to completely bind the radioactively tagged hormone and the hormone in the fluid (plasma) to be assayed. Thus, there is competition between the labeled and endogenous hormone for binding sites on the antibody. Consequently, if the amount of radioactive hormone bound to antibody is low, this finding would indicate that plasma levels of endogenous hormone are high
